title: 111_hr4737
content: The HUD Demonstration Improvement Act of 2010, also known as the HUD Demonstration Act of 1993, has been amended in Section 4. Section 4 of the HUD Demonstration Act of 1993 (42 U.S.C. 9816 note) is amended to allow funding to eligible entities in urban or rural areas for community housing development organizations serving low-income families. The HUD Demonstration Act of 1993 is amended to allow funding for eligible entities in urban or rural areas to support community housing development organizations serving low-income families. Eligible entities must submit a written plan describing how they will use assistance to develop the capacity of community development corporations and housing organizations for community development and affordable housing projects. The eligible entity must demonstrate the need for proposed activities in specific geographic areas, showcase experience in HUD or other housing/economic programs, and outline how outcomes will be measured. The Secretary will distribute funds for implementation. The Secretary will distribute funds for implementation to eligible entities based on their plan's fulfillment of specific requirements, including a minimum amount of assistance equal to 10% of funds and a maximum amount of 50% of funds for any fiscal year. Public availability of plans is required within 30 days. The Secretary must make the plans of eligible entities public on the Department of Housing and Urban Development website within 30 days of providing assistance. An annual report to Congress is required to detail how the assistance is used by community development organizations. Eligible entities include the National Community Development Initiative, Local Initiatives Support Corporation, and The Enterprise Foundation. The eligible entities for assistance include The Enterprise Foundation, Habitat for Humanity, Youthbuild USA, The National Urban League, and The Housing Partnership Network. Funding for fiscal years 2011 through 2015 is increased to $60,000,000.
